comments.commentBody:
@Harrison, I confess to having never read Nietzsche -- I'm not sure if that makes what I've done worse or better.

@Marian, How can you be so sure my error was one of grammar and not of careless typing and inadequate editing? Thank you for bringing it to my attention, regardless.

I think it's already happening. Attitudes toward suicide ("assisted" or not) have changed enormously in my lifetime, and it's largely because people have seen their family members and friends remaining physically alive when all that makes life pleasurable or useful has died. Many people I know (including me) are planning, or at least contemplating, what to do if we ever face that situation ourselves. The oblivion of full death looks preferable to a living death.

@Diana, if you've never read Nietzche, perhaps you Annie Lennox's Cold is a better option

http://youtu.be/VdIbV96t-D4

Specifically, "dying is easy it's living that scares me"

Wouldn't it be ironic if modern medicine, and it's orientation towards postponing death at almost all costs, actually backed us into overcoming our (collective) fear of death, by giving us a "fate worse than death" to contemplate?

Thanks for a poignant story that perfectly embodies the 'show don't tell' ethic. The piece is more powerful for the questions it lets readers answer for themselves.

While I enjoy the multi-media style, I appreciate the thorough research and well-written story much more. Without them multi-media is meaningless.

For those who believe these skiers are extremophiles who had it coming, remember that risk is something we all face every day. It may be obvious, like a car hurtling through a red light, or it may be silent. Potato chips + couch + television kill far more people, and souls, than avalanches ever will. Live, love, and laugh a little louder while you can.

I am both appalled and fascinated by the Stevens Pass avalanche story. I ski Stevens Pass often, although I stick to the designated trails on the east and back sides of Cowboy Mountain. Two cousins of mine have died in avalanches, both expert skiers.

No one who is honest with themselves can read this story and say for sure that they wouldn’t have pushed off down Tunnel Creek. Why? People in groups.

People in groups will do things that no individual would try. There is a good side to this. People in groups will egg each other on, to start new companies and achieve great things. Read the history of Microsoft or Apple. Very few successful startups are created by individuals. There is almost always a small group.

Individuals in a high-performing small group measure themselves by the group. When faced with a challenge, they consider only that others in the group might disapprove, if they couldn’t surmount that challenge.That leads them to achieve at a higher level than they could have previously imagined.

But the dark side of this is the Tunnel Creek story. Another example of the dark side is the way in which leaders of businesses and other institutions focus solely on the internal operation of the organization. The balance sheet is good, the strategic plan is being followed – what could go wrong?

The answer is: outside. The group is not looking outside itself, at the customers or clients. Or at the snow pack, which might be breaking loose

I guess Sandy did not register with Richard...just another storm.

We will see about California's economy in the future as cap and trade makes businesses more energy efficient. I suspect that will give them a long term advantage.

C&T is not actually a tax since one can offset your CO2 emissions. The money goes to people who can show they are sequestering the carbon or cutting their emissions. The funds do not go to the government.

Note that California was "politically correct" on car emissions years ago and states have followed. Be happy you are down wind of California and we who live in California are glad the prevailing winds are not eat to west....Merry Christmas.

In a just world this production would be called out for the high school level a performance that it is. SJ has a one note performance that is painful to watch- she yells for the entire first act and does not once ever approach subtlety. The rest of the cast falls nicely into the easy and predictable stereo typesof the roles.
There is a lot of money and a lot of power behind this production, so no doubt the times and New Yorker will bend over backwards to find something to praise and keep those tourists from the Midwest buying tickets.
In truth this is a tragedy of poor execution and director ashford should stick with musicals; where the audience won't notice when the internal logic of the play no longer makes sense (mr. ashford, she calls them "no neck monsters" because they are rotund; fat if you will, so think it though and cast fat kids - see how understanding the script helps?)

Oh my God, the memories brought back by that photo of a Chemcraft chemistry set....we all had them in my neighborhood circa 1959 to 1962 or so. One of my friends set his house on fire with an improvised explosive mixture ( the main reason for asking for a chemistry set); another set his pants on fire and has massive scarring still at 59. It was inevitable that they'd factor in safeguards eventually. And then there was the Holy Grail of kid mischief, the absolute height of boy pyrotechnic fantasies - my father's (he was an early shooter/reloader) unlocked cabinet with numerous cans of gunpowder. But that's another story....
I have seen these so-called "police" in DC. Dressed in black, wearing armor and carrying an AR15 and a handgun. What kind of police are they? They look more like a private army.
The man who shot and killed the firemen was a convicted felon and wasn't supposed to have a gun regarless of his mental condition.

Did you use the word "deserve"? Oh, my.

Are you suggesting that people like Luke are ENTITLED to be noticed, nurtured and celebrated? Some powerful people in this country think they aren't even entitled to the basics they need for survival.

The conservative Republicans currently holding our nation hostage are determined to slash social programs and shred the social safety net so that millionaires and billionaires won't have to pay a penny more in taxes.

As a practical matter, Americans with disabilities depend even more than the elderly do on Social Security and other taxpayer-supported programs. They are among the 47 percent of the population Mitt Romney unfairly characterized as severely undeserving--people "who are dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims, who believe the government has a responsibility to care for them, who believe that they are entitled to health care, to food, to housing, to you-name-it."

Some Americans think they're entitled to food. How dare they!

There will be no real joys of this season or any other until we face a fact: Under conservative rule, America is a mean-spiritied, stingy, punitive and uncompassionate country. If we want to make any real progress towards fostering better lives for Luke and for all of us, we need to purge the U.S. Congress of people who do not reflect our best selves and our true values.

Bravo to Luke and Laurie Cameron. People come in varied packages and *all* deserve to be noticed, nurtured and celebrated.

Joys of the season to all on this Earth.
Prayer. Gratitude. And another prayer. Anxiety gone.

It's not regret, it's anxiety. And while we may be hardwired for it, when you suffer from it to the degree that the author and many others of us do, it's not adaptive or helpful--it's crippling and debilitating.
Thank you, Bill. You must know how much I needed to hear this from a fellow sufferer. Truly, thanks.

One thing I've learned about anxiety is that you cannot explain it to a person who doesn't have it; like my wife. She is a naturally happy person. After 28 years, I remain in awe of her 'condition'.

For myself, I've tried the meditation,Chinese medicine, the diets, embracing it, and the full variety of 'cures.' I know another way of feeling exists, only because the veil has lifted for a few hours every now and then and I feel at peace and cheerful.

Meanwhile, I'm just glad that people like my wife exist. She makes me smile just by being herself. After 28 years I remain in awe of her consistent moment to moment embrace of a wonderful life. I'm most fortunate to live with Joie De Vie, even though I don't feel it myself.
A cure is something that banishes a medical condition for good, The current drugs for anxiety are simply treatments because you have to take them over and over again.

Two things I've just started trying recently, and so far I'm amazed at their impact, which is supposed to grow with time:  yoga nidra (check out classes/workshops or CDs) and the emWave 2 gadget from HeartMath. Seriously. I was skeptical, but decided to go for it with the 30-day satisfaction guarantee. I will NOT be returning this thing. Google it for more info.
Bill, if you are in Manhattan, I belive a woman named Melissa Tiers can help you achieve your goal. Really. She has helped many others without drugs and in relatively few sessions.

Thank you, Bill Hayes, for your excellent Christmas gift to your readers - and to me. How very timely your article is, I suspect, for many of us as we ready ourselves for family visits over the holidays. I will post your article where I can read it daily and remind myself of what I wish to let go of as I travel my own last quarter of life. Cheers to you and yours for 2013!
It is a profound insult to intelligence that there is no tax-preferenced status for debunking belief in magic.

The "God business" -- in whatever form -- has always been a "profitable line of work indeed". I am dumbfounded by the amount of time, energy and money that keeps being poured into humankind's oldest racket all over the world. Combine this with the historical function of (virtually any) organized religion to legitimize prevailing social, economic, and political structures, and existing elites, and you have a pretty toxic mix. Where else can you make so much money by telling people what they want to hear? Oh, I forgot ... Fox "News."

I'd be curious to know if any calculation has been made of the percentage of national (or global) income that is devoted to religious purposes, and how this has changed over time.

There is a Passionists Fathers retreat center behind my house. It is several acres with oaks and redwoods, I can just make out the building. The have a tax exemption and although I have never been fond of the Catholic religion, I go to their wine and cheese fund raiser once a year. I suggested they let a bee keeper put in a few hives, which they would get paid for, but they would lose their tax exemption if they did that.

For those of us on our side of the street, we do not have any noisy neighbors behind our back yards, just squirrels, skunks, turkeys and finches. I know the gardeners and couple of the fathers, so it is pretty peaceful. They have retreats every week end that are made by many groups. The do not have to be Catholics to use the enter, and they have an AA meeting once a week there.

One natural consequence of this line of inquiry is why churches ought to be exempted from the tax rolls.

In some states and cities, this exemption is applied equally to all nonprofit institutions, for the neutral reason of encouraging acts of public charity and advancement; well and good. But an exemption specifically for churches, by this line of reasoning, would be untenable. Likewise, if a church were to be a profit-making institution, it should enjoy no special treatment compared to other profitable enterprises -- and while many churches these days are dying, a cursory examination of many of the megachurches and established denominations across America suggests that the God business is a profitable line of work indeed.
America's most successful indigenous religion, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, plays every economic advantage gifted to "faith based institutions" for every last penny it is worth.

Pretty sure the C of E has switched over to the Archbishop of Canterbury. And the governing of England has definitely switched over to parliament. It sure was true for Henry VIII though, in a big way.

Dear M,

Religion means a way of interpreting the world.

"Scientism" believes that the human brain can/does define

what is and what is not and can explain the all and why of existence.

It brooks no objections and demands that all meaning must

be filtered through its 'way of being'.

Professor Critchley: Sadly, the comments selected as "Reader Picks" demonstrate not only the abysmal ignorance of even NYTimes readers but how the religion of scientism has so infected supposedly sophisticated minds that the truth of mortal life as paradox is unappreciated.

Well, I guess as you say, let them be happy in their certainty, however misplaced.
Because happiness and freedom are a contradiction in terms, perhaps?  Life makes it that way, perhaps?

I actually read every word of this essay, and I thought I was following it until I got to the end. I think "diabolical happiness or unendurable freedom" is a false dichotomy, even for an institution. How about attempting to acheive happiness and freedom, with neither one being stigmatized as "diabolical" and the admission that both states are, in the absolute, difficult to acheive?

@Bruce Crossan,
No, a belief in "god" is not necessary to explain everything we don't understand. Lack of understanding on my part does mean that you get to invent a universal answer that explains everything I don't know. For centuries scientific understandings have replaced religious understandings. How often has the reverse been true?

No one knows what happened before the universe and time began. The question may be unanswerable, such as asking what is north of the North Pole. But everything we're certain about today was mysterious and uncertain before it was understood. There is no need to abdicate reason and imagine that supernatural beings are the only logical explanation. If the people of Galileo's time had gotten a peek at the world we live in, they could only think it worked by magic. Magic doesn't enter into it, and never has. And rhetorical games like Pascal's Wager don't have the power to undermine rational thought.

Excellent article for this holiday season - some of us will ponder about the final dilemma of the author - " dibolical happiness or unendurable freedom?".The nineteenth century Indian saint Sri Ramakrishna who pursued the path of unendurable freedom explained in one place in "Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna", that when he reached that state of freedom, the happiness was order of magnitude greater than the worldly happiness.

In my mind our only choice to reach the state of happiness is path of freedom. The big question is when we our mind will be able to reach that conclusion through our life's experience.

Well put! Now, as tempting as the illusion of happiness may be, it does not compare to being real. The Grand Inquisitor uses morality to demean others. His entire world view is one of others as lower and less than him. He uses morality to cement his own power rather than meeting people as free persons. He is afraid of their freedom but projects his fear suggesting that they are afraid of freedom. He is the least free of them all. Eugen Drewermann is a contemporary Germany theologian, philosopher and psychoanalyst who is perhaps the closest to a Dostoevsky, a Melvillee or a Kierkegaard. He has written books on the first two authors and made Kierkegaard's analysis of anxiety the cornerstone of a (post)modern theology. In essence, his point is that throwing around "God" to curtail peoples' freedom in the name of delivering them from it is simply a paternalistic ploy, albeit it of unconscious, to control others in order not to face one's own fear of frgeedom! Any Church or religious institution doing so has lost credibility today. The task of religion is not to instrumentalize fear but to provide spaces in which it can be genuinely alleviated.
Does that mean that you advocate legalizing heroin, meth, and cocaine?
Drugs are illegal but people still buy, sell, and use them. So what is a gun ban going to do?
